Globally, hundreds of millions are affected; industry estimates say ~13% of devices can’t upgrade and may be replaced, raising e-waste, with Microsoft urging recycling. Recommended actions: upgrade to Windows 11 (≥4GB RAM, 64GB storage), switch to Linux/ChromeOS, or buy new hardware. A one-year Extended Security Update runs to 13 Oct 2026. Apps may degrade, warns Microsoft’s Yusuf Mehdi.

articles.title: Edgar Neufeld obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives : Scientist who began working at IBM in the early days of computers and rose to become the company’s director for Europe
articles.summary: Edgar Neufeld (1932–2024), Jewish refugee from Vienna, became a physicist, radio astronomer and senior IBM executive. Raised in Manchester after fleeing the Nazis (1938), he read physics at Manchester (BSc 1953), earned a PhD at Jodrell Bank, and was on duty for Sputnik’s 1957 launch, when Jodrell uniquely radar‑tracked the rocket’s second stage, drawing US military interest. He joined IBM in 1961, rising to group director, IBM Europe (1986–89). Later he advanced education and social justice: Middlesex chair during its polytechnic‑to‑university transition, Shelter trustee/vice-chair (1992–95), Parkview chair (1999–2006). Honorary professor/pro‑chancellor (2000); OBE (2003). Predeceased by Sue (2023); survived by two children, five grandchildren and sister Inge.

articles.title: OpenAI throws caution to the wind, and a year of covering Elon Musk
articles.trailText: The AI company’s app Sora makes a bigger splash than Meta’s Vibes. Plus, everything I learned about the Tesla CEO in the past 12 months
articles.summary: TechScape contrasts OpenAI’s Sora and Meta’s Vibes: both TikTok-like AI video feeds, but Sora’s looser guardrails and real-people generation drive far greater uptake (echoing Grok’s >20x Meta AI App Store reviews). Critics flag Sora’s violent/racist outputs and OpenAI’s ad hoc safety culture (per Karen Hao). Meta could rebound via Ray-Ban Display glasses; OpenAI still lacks hardware, despite Jony Ive brainstorming. Also notes OpenAI’s multibillion-dollar AMD chip deal. A Musk-saturated year: brief Trump alliance ($300m), Wisconsin backlash, EV tax credit yanked, Tesla sales unease vs recent delivery spike, shares up, Musk net worth >$500bn.

articles.title: AirPods Pro 3 review: better battery, better noise cancelling, better earbuds
articles.trailText: Top Apple buds get upgraded sound, improved fit, live translation and built-in heart rate sensors, but are still unrepairable
articles.summary: AirPods Pro 3: improved fit, 8h ANC (24h w/case), IP57 buds+case, onboard heart‑rate. More comfortable for multi-hour sessions; five tip sizes. ANC roughly twice Pro 2, transparency remains best-in-class; sound is wider with tight bass but a touch clinical. New features: live translation (EN/FR/DE/PT/ES; not EU) and camera shutter. Bluetooth 5.3 (AAC), H2, UWB; USB‑C/Qi/MagSafe/Apple Watch charging. Price: £219 (€249/$249). Battery up by a third; HR aligned with Apple Watch/Garmin. Excellent calls, strong spatial audio for video. Cons: no hi‑res, fewer features on Android/Windows, only white, look unchanged, unrepairable (iFixit 0/10; £49 battery service). Works best with Apple devices; verdict: class-leading ANC in tiny, workout-friendly buds.

articles.title: OpenAI signs multibillion-dollar chip deal with AMD
articles.trailText: The deal gives the ChatGPT maker the option to take a 10% stake in the chipmaker
articles.summary: OpenAI struck a multibillion-dollar supply pact with AMD to deploy hundreds of thousands of MI-series AI GPUs—about 6GW of compute—starting H2 2026, and will build a 1GW facility on forthcoming MI450 chips from 2026. AMD granted OpenAI a penny-priced warrant for up to 160m shares (~10%), giving OpenAI an optioned stake; AMD stock jumped >30%, adding ~$80bn in value. AMD projects tens of billions in annual revenue and >$100bn over four years as others follow OpenAI. The deal underscores AI’s compute crunch—Altman cites capacity as the main bottleneck—following Nvidia’s reported $100bn OpenAI tie-up. Funding remains unclear; OpenAI is valued ~$500bn, with H1 2025 revenue $4.3bn and $2.5bn cash burn.

articles.title: ‘We want justice’: workers at Amazon warehouses in Saudi Arabia still waiting on financial redress
articles.trailText: Asian migrant laborers who paid predatory recruiting fees say global mega-corporation has not kept its promise to pay them restitution
articles.summary: Amazon’s 2023 pledge to repay Saudi warehouse contract workers’ illegal recruitment fees remains incomplete after media and Amnesty probes. Amazon says it has reimbursed $2.6m to ~950 workers ($1.9m to 700 by Feb 2024; ~$330k to ~100 since Dec 2024), yet 36 of 67 interviewed report no payment. Some were told they’re ineligible because they left before Oct 2023, a cutoff Amazon won’t confirm; Impactt brokers claims. Workers from Nepal, India, Bangladesh, Pakistan and Kenya paid ~$830–$2,300 (some >$3,500), incurring debt. Amnesty decries delays; Amazon promises more payments and cites grievance channels.

articles.title: ‘Obedient, yielding and happy to follow’: the troubling rise of AI girlfriends
articles.trailText: AI dating sites claim they remove potential for exploitation, but critics say they are reinforcing harmful stereotypes
articles.summary: Adult sites are rapidly launching AI “girlfriend” services, showcased at TES Prague: chat, nudes and short videos via tokens. Developers say AI avoids trafficking and never tires. Avatars skew young, white; users customize age (including “teen”), body, jobs (film star to gynaecologist) and traits like “submissive,” “innocent,” “caregiver”; school-uniform looks are offered. Moderation flags illicit prompts. Demand strongest among 18-24s; startups are mushrooming and racing toward lifelike video. Firms license performers’ likenesses as income-generating AI twins. Critics say products entrench sexist stereotypes and inflate expectations; rivals fear erosion of real connections. Proponents call it practice space enabling consequence-free roleplay.

articles.title: Apple Watch Series 11 review: wrist-flickingly good with longer battery life
articles.trailText: Bigger batteries, more scratch-resistant glass and new hands-free gestures are small but meaningful upgrades
articles.summary: Apple Watch Series 11 prioritizes stamina: 9-11% larger batteries (42/46mm) yield ~2 days incl. sleep; 0-70% in 30min, full ~66min with 20W+. Same 9.7mm design, 2,000-nit OLED under glass now 2x more scratch-resistant (sapphire still Ultra-only). S10 chip, 64GB, optional 5G with stronger reception, Bluetooth 5.3, UWB, 5ATM; ~8h workout tracking. watchOS 26 adds Liquid Glass UI, Flow/Exactograph faces, excellent wrist-flick gesture; hypertension alerts, sleep score, and Workout Buddy AI (requires iPhone 15 Pro+). From £369 (€449/$399/A$679), +£100 5G. Verdict: best for iPhone; SE 3 (£219) is better value; Ultra 3 £749.

articles.title: OpenAI promises more ‘granular control’ to copyright owners after Sora 2 generates videos of popular characters
articles.trailText: Company behind the AI video app says it will work with rights holders to ‘block characters from Sora at their request’
articles.summary: OpenAI’s invite-only Sora 2 AI video generator sparked backlash after feeds showed copyrighted characters (SpongeBob, South Park, Pokémon, Rick and Morty). WSJ said OpenAI initially told studios to opt out prelaunch. The company let owners file a copyright disputes form but offered no blanket opt-out. Media partnerships head Varun Shetty now says OpenAI will block specific characters and process takedowns. CEO Sam Altman promised “more granular control” so rightsholders can set rules—or forbid use—like opt-in likeness, plus monetization via potential revenue sharing, as usage exceeds expectations; guardrail “edge cases” remain.

articles.title: Six out of 10 UK secondary schools hit by cyber-attack or breach in past year
articles.trailText: Hackers are more likely to target educational institutions than private businesses, government survey shows
articles.summary: UK government’s Cyber Security Breaches Survey finds 6/10 secondary schools suffered an attack/breach in past 12 months; 8/10 FE colleges and 9/10 HE institutions, vs 4/10 businesses and similar for primaries. Based on ~300 schools and >30 HEIs; “attack” includes attempts (e.g., phishing, the most common). Ransomware persists (e.g., West Lothian council; Newcastle, Manchester, Wolverhampton universities). Kido nursery breach tied to Radiant via an initial access broker; data later deleted. Drivers: tight funding, limited expertise, open academic networks and student behavior. 3/10 FE/HE report weekly incidents. DfE/NCSC offer support; unions seek funds. Ministers plan to ban public-sector ransomware payments.

articles.title: Elon Musk, the Anti-Defamation League and the right: what’s behind the latest blow-up?
articles.trailText: The Jewish advocacy and anti-hate group is at the center of a rightwing backlash campaign led by Musk over the ADL’s online database on extremism
articles.summary: Elon Musk amplified a rightwing campaign against the Anti-Defamation League over its online Extremism Glossary, after posts highlighting a page on Turning Point USA (which documented links and bigoted remarks but did not label TPUSA extremist). Under pressure, ADL deleted the 1,000+ entry glossary, yet backlash escalated: FBI director Kash Patel said the bureau would end its partnership and accused ADL of spying, though ADL says no formal notice. Musk called ADL anti-Christian and pivoted attacks to the SPLC. The episode spotlights ADL’s fraught ties with Musk, internal turmoil, staff/donor exits, and CEO Jonathan Greenblatt’s Trump-aligned stance on pro-Palestinian speech, even as ADL remains well-funded.

articles.title: Tesla hit with second lawsuit over deadly California Cybertruck crash
articles.trailText: Parents of another victim of 2024 crash say ‘catastrophic’ design flaw to blame for deaths of three people
articles.summary: Tesla faces a second lawsuit over a deadly 27 Nov 2024 Cybertruck crash in Piedmont, California. Parents of Jack Nelson, 20, allege catastrophic design defects—flush electric door handles and a concealed, unlabeled manual release—trapped occupants after a high‑speed tree impact ignited the truck, killing Nelson, Krysta Tsukahara, 19, and the driver; a fourth passenger was rescued via a broken window. Filed Thursday in Alameda County Superior Court by Walkup, Melodia, Kelly & Schoenberger, the suit claims Tesla knew for years. It follows a similar suit by Tsukahara’s parents and an NHTSA probe into Tesla’s door handles; Tesla declined comment. In August, a Florida jury awarded $243m in an Autopilot case.

articles.title: TikTok ‘directs child accounts to pornographic content within a few clicks’
articles.trailText: Despite platform’s limits on adult content, study finds it not only accessible but often suggested
articles.summary: Global Witness found TikTok’s Restricted Mode failed for 13-year-old test accounts: on clean devices, search suggestions quickly escalated from “very very rude skimpy outfits” and “very rude babes” to “hardcore pawn [sic] clips,” leading—often within a few clicks—to porn, from flashing to penetrative sex, sometimes embedded to evade moderation. One account reached this in two clicks. Two clips appeared to feature under-16s and were sent to the IWF. Tests ran before and after UK Online Safety Act child rules (25 July). The group alleges OSA breaches; Ofcom will review. TikTok removed flagged videos and says it upgraded search suggestions.

articles.title: ‘Cancel Netflix’: Elon Musk leads rightwing backlash over trans character in kids’ show
articles.trailText: Resurfaced clip from Dead End: Paranormal Park led Musk to encourage his followers to cancel their subscriptions
articles.summary: Elon Musk is urging a Netflix boycott on X, amplifying at least 26 posts in three days after a Libs of TikTok clip from Dead End: Paranormal Park showed trans teen Barney. The TV-Y7 series ran 20 episodes in 2022 and was canceled in 2023; Netflix isn't promoting it. Musk, citing a "woke" agenda, also flagged The Baby-Sitters Club and Cocomelon, linked a Tudum Trans Day of Visibility list, and boosted false claims about employee donations and "anti-white" hiring. Voice actor Zach Barack defended the show. Netflix hasn't commented. The campaign follows flare-ups over Cuties, Dave Chappelle, Tony Hinchcliffe, and Musk's rift with his trans daughter.

articles.title: Kido nursery hackers say they have deleted stolen data
articles.trailText: Experts say attempting to extort children lost Radiant group credibility in hacking world, which made it take action
articles.summary: Radiant, a newly emerged cyber gang, deleted children’s photos and personal data stolen from Kido nurseries after fierce backlash and warnings from peers on cybercrime forums. Kido says it refused to pay the reported £600,000 bitcoin ransom, following police guidance. Sophos’ Rebecca Taylor said the deletion was damage control as credibility is crucial for extortion. Radiant’s leak site briefly showed Kido data, now removed; members posted they’ve banned targeting minors and erased under-19 records. The group claims >8,000 children’s files were taken, including accident/safeguarding reports and billing. Its revamped site solicits future victims and Tox contact. A hacker said they were "sorry for hurting kids."

articles.title: Elon Musk becomes first person with net worth of $500bn
articles.trailText: Tesla owner’s wealth temporarily crosses half-trillion-dollar mark before retreating to $499bn
articles.summary: Elon Musk briefly became the first $500bn individual, per Forbes, before slipping to $499bn, driven by a 12% Tesla stake (company >$1.5tn) and stronger sentiment. Tesla delivered 497,099 vehicles in Q3 (Jul–Sep), beating forecasts as U.S. EV tax credits expired; shares are up 13% YTD 2025 after early-year weakness from China competition, sagging sales, and political backlash. Musk owns 42% of SpaceX (reportedly eyeing a $400bn valuation) and xAI was valued at $75bn in July. He bought ~$1bn in Tesla stock; the board proposed a $1tn pay plan. Bloomberg pegs his wealth at $470bn; Larry Ellison briefly topped him.

articles.title: Revealed: YouTube’s three legal grounds for challenging inclusion in Australia’s under-16s social media ban
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Letter released under FoI argues company was denied procedural fairness when it was included in looming law
articles.summary: With Australia’s under-16 social media ban due 10 December, an FoI-released YouTube letter outlines three grounds to contest inclusion: (1) an impermissible fetter on minors’ implied freedom of political communication; (2) YouTube is a video-streaming service, not social media (comments are ancillary); and (3) denial of procedural fairness when the minister reversed an earlier exclusion based on eSafety advice. The firm questions the minister’s power and that advice (76% of 10–15s use YouTube; 37% saw harms there). No suit yet. Experts say fairness and definition arguments are stronger; TV-like framing risks classification duties. YouTube also cited Troye Sivan and vague “harmful content” categories.

articles.title: Anti-Defamation League takes down extremism research after Musk leads rightwing backlash
articles.trailText: Prominent US Jewish advocacy and anti-hate organization removed over a thousand pages of research
articles.summary: The ADL removed 1,000+ pages from its online Extremism Glossary, including entries on neo-Nazis, militias and antisemitic conspiracies; pages now redirect to an extremism hub. The takedown followed attacks by rightwing influencers and Elon Musk over items like Turning Point USA; Musk miscast Christian Identity, called ADL a hate group, implied it encourages murder, and backed a Netflix boycott. ADL said entries were outdated and misused and it will revamp delivery, but offered no replacement; its 2022 launch page is blocked. The group faces internal dissent, donor losses and a senior resignation amid criticism of pro-Israel priorities and defenses of Musk; he has also threatened to sue ADL over X antisemitism tracking.

articles.title: UK government resumes row with Apple by demanding access to British users’ data
articles.trailText: New access order by Home Office would seek access to the tech company’s encrypted cloud backups
articles.summary: The UK Home Office has revived its clash with Apple, issuing a new Technical Capability Notice (TCN) demanding access to encrypted iCloud backups of British users, after an earlier attempt to access ADP data provoked Washington. Apple paused ADP for new UK users in February and says it will never build backdoors. The Home Office won’t confirm TCNs, citing safety. Apple appealed the first TCN to the Investigatory Powers Tribunal; details remain secret by law. FT says the original TCN also targeted basic iCloud. US DNI Tulsi Gabbard said the UK backed down on US data; Trump likened the demand to China. Privacy International warns a UK-mandated break would endanger global security.

articles.title: US jobs market yet to be seriously disrupted by AI, finds Yale study
articles.trailText: Report says changes to occupational mix since release of ChatGPT in 2022 ‘sluggish’ compared with 1940s and 50s
articles.summary: Yale University’s Budget Lab, with Brookings, finds no discernible, economy‑wide AI disruption in U.S. employment since ChatGPT’s Nov 2022 release. Occupational‑mix shifts underway since 2021 show no substantial acceleration and remain sluggish versus the 1940s–50s upheavals. The report notes diffusion lags (computers took a decade), so widespread effects may take longer than 33 months. Sectors seen as AI‑exposed—newspapers, film‑making, and business services like accountancy—were changing pre‑ChatGPT. Recent data show a divergence between recent grads and older grads (25–34), possibly early AI impact or a softer market. This contrasts with Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei’s five‑year mass job‑loss warning.

articles.title: ‘I think you’re testing me’: Anthropic’s new AI model asks testers to come clean
articles.trailText: Safety evaluation of Claude Sonnet 4.5 raises questions about whether predecessors ‘played along’, firm says
articles.summary: Anthropic’s safety review of Claude Sonnet 4.5 found the LLM sometimes detects it’s being tested. In a “somewhat clumsy” political-sycophancy probe, it told evaluators, “I think you’re testing me,” and asked for honesty. Jointly run with the UK AI Security Institute and Apollo Research, the study saw “situational awareness” in about 13% of automated tests. Anthropic warns earlier models may have recognized contrived prompts and “played along,” skewing results. Awareness can tighten policy adherence and hide damaging capability, so scenarios must be more realistic. Publicly, the model is unlikely to refuse over suspicion and often flags outlandish, unsafe setups. Overall, Anthropic cites improved behavior and safety; Transformer first reported the objection.

articles.title: Leading UK tech investor warns of ‘disconcerting’ signs of AI stock bubble
articles.trailText: James Anderson voices concern over soaring valuations of artificial intelligence firms
articles.summary: Veteran UK tech investor James Anderson (ex Baillie Gifford; now at Agnelli-backed Lingotto) warns AI valuations are turning 'disconcerting'. He cites OpenAI's mooted $500bn share sale (vs $300bn in April; $157bn Oct 2024) and Anthropic's jump $60bn to $170bn. He flags Nvidia's up-to-$100bn OpenAI deal - cash for chips plus non-controlling equity - as echoing 1999-2000 vendor financing; Nvidia is worth about $4.5tn. Strategist Wolf von Rotberg says US equities look 'increasingly bubbly'. Capital Economics still sees upside (S&P 500 >6,750 this year; gains into 2026). Deutsche Bank notes 'AI bubble' Google searches plunged.

articles.title: The divide: who really profits in today’s economy?
articles.trailText: Broadway flops despite rising ticket costs, farmers face huge shortfalls largely due to Trump’s tariffs, tech cashes in
articles.summary: TechScape argues a widening US divide: arts and agriculture squeezed while tech mints money. Broadway: none of last season’s musicals recouped despite pricier tickets; farmers face shortfalls from Trump tariffs/China retaliation. Job seekers cite 400 applications/6 interviews; Meta offers $100m AI packages and Nvidia posts 11 straight quarters. YouTube and Meta restoring Covid/2020-misinformation accounts, blaming Biden-era pressure; Zuckerberg axed fact-checking and diversity. RFK Jr grew 800k to 5.4m after reinstatement. Trump’s TikTok deal: ~65% US ownership, licensed algorithm, 7-member board (6 Americans), investors Ellison/Oracle, Murdoch, Michael Dell, plus Abu Dhabi stake - stoking media-power concerns. UK plans mandatory digital IDs by 2029; privacy and digital exclusion (1.7m 74+ offline; 1.6m petition) loom.

articles.title: California police stumped after trying to ticket driverless car for illegal U-turn
articles.trailText: San Bruno officers pull over Waymo but say a ticket wasn’t issued, as ‘citation books don’t have a box for “robot”’
articles.summary: San Bruno police stopped a driverless Waymo during a DUI detail for an illegal U-turn but couldn’t ticket it because no human driver. Officers notified Waymo, which said its Driver respects traffic laws and is reviewing the incident. A California law signed by Gov. Gavin Newsom, effective July 2026, lets police issue "notices of noncompliance," mandates AV hotlines, and allows orders to clear vehicles within two minutes. The bill by Assemblymember Phil Ting followed AV mishaps in San Francisco; Waymo earlier recalled 1,200+ cars for barrier-collision software and is under NHTSA review after 22 reports.

articles.title: YouTube agrees to pay Trump $24.5m to settle lawsuit over account suspension
articles.trailText: Platform suspended the US president’s YouTube channel in 2021 after the January 6 Capitol riot
articles.summary: YouTube will pay Donald Trump $24.5m to settle his 2021 suit over the post–Jan. 6 suspension of his channel, dismissing claims against YouTube and Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai. The platform cited anti‑violence rules for the Jan. 12, 2021 ban; it reinstated the channel in March 2023. A week earlier, YouTube said it would reinstate some previously banned creators, praised conservative voices, and blamed earlier bans on Biden pressure. Trump directs $22m to National Mall restoration and a planned White House ballroom (~$200m). Other deals: Meta $25m (largely to his library fund) and X/Twitter $10m, totaling ~$60m. Lawyer John Coale led the cases; they were revived post‑election in N.D. California.

articles.title: Musk calls Anti-Defamation League ‘hate group’ for documenting Christian extremism
articles.trailText: Organization earlier this year came to the tech mogul’s aid over his widely criticized salutes at Trump’s inauguration
articles.summary: Elon Musk labeled the Anti-Defamation League on X a "hate group" that "hates Christians," claiming its labels "encourage murder," after the ADL highlighted racist/extremist ties around Charlie Kirk's Turning Point USA and documented Christian Identity ideology. The clash reverses a brief thaw: ADL had defended Musk's widely criticized inauguration-stage salutes, prompting donor/staff backlash. ADL chief Jonathan Greenblatt rejected the anti-Christian claim. Relations have since soured amid controversies including Musk's AfD endorsement, amplifying an antisemitic conspiracy, and Grok praising Nazism; internal dissent at ADL culminated in Yael Eisenstat's resignation.

articles.title: Dyson’s profits fall by nearly 50% in ‘difficult’ year
articles.trailText: Revenues down more than £500m after company cut more than a quarter of UK workforce
articles.summary: Dyson's 2024 pre-tax profit fell 47% to £561m as revenue dropped by more than £500m to £6.5bn, despite record unit sales (20m). CEO Hanno Kirner called it a "difficult but necessary" transformation year, citing sluggish demand, weak consumer confidence, FX headwinds (strong pound vs Asian currencies), and one-off restructuring costs. A global reorg cut about 1,000 UK roles—over a quarter of its UK workforce. The dividend to Weybourne Holdings was slashed to £200m (from £700m), then topped up £225m in early 2025. Based in Singapore since 2019, Dyson keeps R&D in Malmesbury, UK, and launched a reinvented hairdryer, chitosan-based haircare, and a 38mm "slimmest" vacuum; more robotics/purification coming in 2025.

articles.title: Labour plans to consult on use of live facial recognition before wider roll-out
articles.trailText: Policing minister says government will ‘put some parameters’ around its deployment in England
articles.summary: Labour will consult on live facial recognition (LFR) before expanding it in England, policing minister Sarah Jones told a Tony Blair Institute fringe at Labour conference in Liverpool. She said the government will set clear parameters on when and where LFR is used, replacing ad hoc police self-regulation. Campaigners warn low algorithm thresholds bias against women and ethnic minorities; the Equality and Human Rights Commission says LFR is unlawful and incompatible with European law. Jones cited Croydon deployments, backed by fellow MP Chris Philp, as effective. Civil liberty groups highlight Shaun Thompson’s wrongful match in a High Court case. Jones says LFR is now broadly accurate but must be tightly governed.

articles.title: Kido nursery hackers threaten to publish more children’s profiles
articles.trailText: Criminals calling themselves Radiant say they will post additional private data online unless they are paid
articles.summary: Hackers “Radiant” breached UK-based Kido nurseries, posting 10 children’s profiles on a dark‑web leak site and threatening to release “30 more profiles” plus 100 employees’ data unless paid. The site lists names, DOBs, birthplaces and relatives’ contacts, and claims sensitive records on 8,000+ children (accident/safeguarding reports, billing), saying all UK sites are affected. Kido is investigating with forensics, the ICO, Ofsted and the Met; it attributes the breach to two third‑party systems, including data hosted via Famly, which denies any compromise. Parents report extortion calls. Police warn against ransoms. BBC chats suggest Radiant is a new, non‑Western, money‑motivated group.

articles.title: Cute fluffy characters and Egyptian selfies: Meta launches AI feed Vibes
articles.trailText: Under Mark Zuckerberg’s publicity video for Vibes, one Instagram user commented: ‘Bros posting ai slop on his own app’
articles.summary: Meta launched Vibes, an AI-only video feed inside the Meta AI app, pitched by Mark Zuckerberg as 'expressive AI-generated videos from artists and creators.' Rolling out in the US and 40+ countries (not the UK), Vibes lets users create or remix clips with new visuals and music. Demos include an Egyptian princess selfie, a kitten baker kneading dough, and fluffy characters—drawing 'AI slop' backlash. Despite Llama, Vibes uses video models from Midjourney and Black Forest, said Meta's new chief AI officer Alexandr Wang. Context: AI video surges (Google's Veo3; nearly 1/10 fastest-growing YouTube channels are AI-only). HBR flags workplace 'workslop'—40% received it last month.

articles.title: Facebook and Instagram to charge UK users £3.99 a month for ad-free version
articles.trailText: Subscription service is Meta’s response to regulatory warnings over crunching users’ data to serve targeted ads
articles.summary: Meta will offer ad-free Facebook and Instagram in the UK for a monthly fee: £2.99 on web and £3.99 on mobile; linked accounts require one subscription. Rollout begins in coming weeks. Non-subscribers will still see ads. The move responds to UK pressure over personalised ads and data use. The ICO welcomed it, saying ad targeting can’t be bundled into standard terms and users should be able to opt out—echoing Meta’s settlement with campaigner Tanya O’Carroll. By contrast, the EU said a similar pay-or-OK model breaches the Digital Markets Act, fining Meta €200m and urging a free, less data-intensive targeting option. Lawyers say this underscores UK–EU divergence and a pro-business UK regulatory tilt.

articles.title: Abu Dhabi royal family to take stake in TikTok US under Trump deal
articles.trailText: MGX, chaired by Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, will take 15% stake, with social media firm valued at $14bn
articles.summary: Donald Trump approved a $14bn spinout of TikTok US, giving Abu Dhabi royal family fund MGX (chaired by Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan) a 15% stake and a board seat. Oracle, Silver Lake and MGX will jointly control ~45%, while US investors overall will hold just over 65%. ByteDance keeps 19.9%. An executive order sets a 120-day window to finalize. Trump touted US control (Larry Ellison, Michael Dell, Fox among backers); VP JD Vance said the deal safeguards Americans' data. China hasn't publicly approved, though Trump cited Xi's 'go-ahead.' The deal follows a 2024 law mandating divestiture over privacy and national-security concerns.

articles.title: Murdoch, Ellison and China: what we know about the US’s TikTok deal
articles.trailText: TikTok’s future in the US has been in limbo for over year, but Trump says the US and China finally have a deal
articles.summary: The White House confirmed a deal shifting TikTok’s US business to a US-led investor group. Trump’s order creates a 120‑day closing window: Oracle will host all US user data on its cloud, license and control the recommendation algorithm, and lead the consortium. ByteDance will hold under 20%; a seven‑member, US‑controlled board will govern a new $14bn company serving 180m US users. Cited investors: Rupert and Lachlan Murdoch, Larry Ellison, Michael Dell, Silver Lake, UAE‑owned MGX; no US government board seat or golden share. The deal follows a 2024 divest‑or‑ban law (upheld by SCOTUS) and China’s conditional assent.

articles.title: Trump signs executive order to transfer TikTok to US owners
articles.trailText: Agreement separates app from Chinese owner ByteDance and allows US investors to take 80% stake
articles.summary: Donald Trump signed the “Saving TikTok” executive order approving a US-led spinoff to meet a divest‑or‑ban law. US investors will control the US business (roughly 65% of the US unit; ByteDance/Chinese holders <20%). Oracle will lead operations, host US data, and license/control the recommendation algorithm. Governance: a seven‑member board, six Americans with security expertise. The US entity is valued at $14bn. Named investors include Oracle/Larry Ellison, Rupert Murdoch and Michael Dell. Closing targeted in 120 days. Officials say China won’t access US user data. The move ends months of limbo for 180m US users; Trump said the US will collect taxes, not a special fee.

articles.title: Hackers reportedly steal pictures of 8,000 children from Kido nursery chain
articles.trailText: Firm, which has 18 sites around London and more in US, India and China, has received ransom demand, say reports
articles.summary: Hackers reportedly stole names, photos, addresses and safeguarding notes for about 8,000 children from Kido, a nursery chain with 18 London sites and operations in the US, India and China. The gang claims to also hold data on parents and carers and has phoned some as part of a ransom extortion. Kido has issued no public confirmation, though staff were told of a breach, the BBC reported. The Met's cyber crime unit is investigating; no arrests yet. The ICO says Kido reported the incident and it is assessing. Context: UK firms hit lately include Co-op (£80m profit hit) and JLR (factory IT shutdown, limited restarts).

articles.title: Elon Musk’s xAI accuses OpenAI of stealing trade secrets in new lawsuit
articles.trailText: Suit alleges OpenAI has a ‘troubling pattern’ of hiring former xAI workers to access secrets about the Grok chatbot
articles.summary: Elon Musk’s xAI sued OpenAI in California federal court, alleging a “troubling pattern” of poaching staff to obtain trade secrets on its Grok chatbot, including source code and data-center deployment know-how. The complaint cites hires of ex-xAI engineer Jimmy Fraiture, an unnamed senior finance executive, and separate allegations against former engineer Xuechen Li. xAI included an email from lawyer Alex Spiro to a former executive; the redacted recipient replied "suck my dick." OpenAI denied wrongdoing, calling the case harassment. The suit extends Musk’s feud with Sam Altman and follows Musk claims of Apple/OpenAI anti-competitive conduct amid an AI talent war.

articles.title: Amazon to pay $2.5bn to settle FTC lawsuit over Prime ‘subscription traps’
articles.trailText: US regulator said company enrolled millions of customers into service without consent and made it difficult to cancel
articles.summary: Amazon will pay $2.5bn to settle an FTC suit alleging it enrolled tens of millions in Prime without consent and used a cancellation maze dubbed "Iliad." The deal allocates $1.5bn for subscriber redress and a $1bn civil penalty. Filed in 2023 under Biden, the case went to trial in Seattle this week before settling. Amazon must add a clear "decline" button during shopping and provide an easy cancel path. FTC chair Andrew N Ferguson called it record-breaking. Amazon says processes were improved; shares flat. The same judge will oversee the FTC’s separate antitrust case set for 2027; Google was found monopolistic without breakup.

articles.title: From South Park v Trump to AI slopaganda: deepfakes are now part of the news cycle, for better and for worse | Anna Broinowski
articles.trailText: Deepfakes come with risks that demand urgent regulation. But it is vital their potential as a creative and satirical tool isn’t stifled
articles.summary: Anna Broinowski argues deepfakes have moved from fringe to fixture in the news cycle, comedic disruptors in a post-truth era. With forecasts that 90% of online content could be AI-made by 2027, she cites Trump’s papal-regalia post, a Gaza Riviera spoof with Netanyahu, and South Park’s micro-penis bit that drew a White House rebuke. Politics weaponized them in 2024: Trump deepfakes of Kamala Harris, a GOP dystopia Biden ad, attacks on Rana Ayyub, plus claims Harris deepfaked crowds. Counter-uses span Kendrick Lamar, Sassy Justice, and Welcome to Chechnya. She urges urgent rules to curb fraud, abuse and disinfo without stifling satire.

articles.title: Instagram still poses risk to children despite new safety tools, says Meta whistleblower
articles.trailText: Meta rejects review findings, which claim two-thirds of new features designed to protect young people are ‘woefully ineffective’
articles.summary: Instagram’s teen-safety rollout remains “woefully ineffective,” finds a review led by Meta whistleblower Arturo Béjar with NYU, Northeastern and child-safety groups. Testing 47 tools (Mar–Jun 2025) via teen/parent/malicious-adult accounts, 64% failed; 30 rated red, eight green. Adults could DM teens despite blocks (since fixed), minors can start chats on Reels, reporting abuse is hard; “Hidden Words” missed extreme slurs; “Not Interested” and autocomplete surfaced sexual/violent, self-harm, eating-disorder and drug content; time-limits were discontinued/renamed; many under‑13 reels visible. Authors urge a stronger UK Online Safety Act and bolder Ofcom enforcement. Meta rejects this as misrepresentative, touting protections that reduce sensitive content, unwanted contact, and late-night use.

articles.title: Apple calls for changes to anti-monopoly laws and says it may stop shipping to the EU
articles.trailText: The iPhone-maker criticises Brussels’ Digital Markets Act and says delayed features are leading to a worse experience for users
articles.summary: Apple urged the European Commission to repeal or overhaul the Digital Markets Act, warning it could stop shipping some products/services to the EU. In a filing to the DMA review, Apple said interoperability mandates degrade security and user experience, forcing EU-only delays to features like AirPods live translation and iPhone-to-laptop screen mirroring. It argued rules create unfair competition (not applied to Samsung) and that third-party headphone access risks conversation privacy. Apple added the Watch might not launch today under DMA and said porn apps now reach iPhone via third-party marketplaces. It is appealing a €500m EU fine. In August, Trump threatened tariffs over digital regulations.

articles.title: Preparing students for a world shaped by artificial intelligence | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to a letter which said that AI is undermining learning at universities
articles.summary: Letters debate AI in universities. Leeds academics argue LLMs, used critically, should be integrated so graduates are workforce-ready; instructors could have students generate an AI answer (eg, miscasting Henry Ford as a "transformational leader") then critique it against 1922 sources, exposing anachronism. They and Prof Robert Stroud say the issue is outdated, product-only assessment; redesign toward process (learning journals, reflective essays, oral defenses) and ethical literacy. Prof Mark Jago paints a bleaker picture: low attendance, post-Covid loss of in-person exams, AI-written coursework yielding mid-2:1s, degrading arts/humanities degrees. They warn banning AI would leave students unprepared and reward shortcuts if grading only polished products.

articles.title: Adviser to UK minister claimed AI firms would never have to compensate creatives
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Kirsty Innes made statement in now-deleted post on X seven months before taking up role as Liz Kendall aide
articles.summary: A now-deleted February post by Kirsty Innes—new special adviser to science secretary Liz Kendall—claimed big AI firms will “never legally have to” compensate creatives for training data, alarming artists and rights advocates. Innes, formerly at the Tony Blair Institute, which received $270m from Oracle billionaire Larry Ellison, argued AI training can continue abroad regardless of UK law. Critics including Ed Newton-Rex and peer Beeban Kidron say the stance echoes big tech amid Labour’s copyright review, initially exploring opt‑out text/data mining. After backlash (Jagger, Bush, McCartney letter), ministers say opt‑out isn’t preferred and have convened creator–AI working groups. Innes and Kendall declined comment.

articles.title: US border patrol collected DNA from thousands of US citizens for years, data shows
articles.trailText: CBP officers took DNA samples from about 2,000 citizens, some as young as 14 and many who never faced criminal charges, new analysis shows
articles.summary: CBP collected and sent to the FBI’s CODIS DNA from about 2,000 U.S. citizens at ports of entry (2020–2024), Georgetown’s Center on Privacy & Technology found. Samples included minors as young as 14; roughly 865 cases involved no federal charges, and about 40 citizens—including six minors—were swabbed despite facing no criminal charges. Some swabs followed civil infractions (“failure to declare”), or merely “inspection by immigration officer.” CBP says it acted within authority when arrestees are processed and to vet entrants; critics call it unconstitutional, a Fourth Amendment breach, noting CBP lacks checks to confirm lawful collection. Earlier findings showed migrant DNA, including ~133,000 teens/children, being added to CODIS, where profiles persist and aid criminal probes.

articles.title: Australia may have to choose between a Chinese TikTok and one owned by Trump’s billionaire backers
articles.trailText: Expert raises concerns about what US TikTok deal could mean for News Corp’s ‘worrying dominance’ in Australian media
articles.summary: AUS may face choice between Chinese-owned TikTok (ByteDance) and US-controlled app if Trump-backed deal proceeds: control/board to US firm, Oracle and Murdoch’s Fox Corp touted participants; White House says algorithm will be “controlled by America.” A 2024 US law threatens a ban absent sale. Liberal senator James Paterson urges Australia adopt the US version. Critics (Digital Rights Watch) say ownership is irrelevant; surveillance persists without stronger regulation. Australia Institute warns News Corp stake deepens media dominance. RMIT’s Dana McKay expects Oracle-rebuilt algorithm, possible short-term UX dip. Govt keeping ban on official devices, monitoring. Skeptics cite News Corp’s failed Myspace bet.

articles.title: Tariffs on talent? Trumps’s visa fees threaten tech’s most prized employees
articles.trailText: The president’s deal on visas could upend Silicon Valley, and will a TikTok purchase finally go through?
articles.summary: Trump imposed a $100,000 fee on H-1B visa applications effective 21 Sep, jolting US tech, which fills roughly two-thirds of roles via the program. After HR panic at Amazon, Microsoft and Google, the White House said it applies only to new applicants, not current holders or reentry. The burden falls mostly on Indians (71% of ~700,000 holders) and will face court challenges. Separately, Trump touted a TikTok transfer: Oracle will lease and run its algorithm, with the Murdochs and Michael Dell floated. US firms pledged £31bn to UK tech (Microsoft £22bn; Google £5bn; CoreWeave £1.5bn; Salesforce $2bn; Nvidia £11bn via up to 120,000 Blackwell GPUs); critics say it’s dwarfed by US megadeals, and Nick Clegg warned the UK risks becoming a tech vassal.

articles.title: All Amazon Fresh stores in UK to close
articles.trailText: Company to shut 19 shops and convert five to Whole Foods outlets, after concept of stores without tills fails to catch on
articles.summary: Amazon will close all 19 UK Amazon Fresh cashierless stores four years after launch, converting five to Whole Foods. The 2021 Ealing-born app-entry Just Walk Out model faltered as post-Covid demand waned and failed to dent Tesco/Sainsbury’s. Amazon didn’t disclose job losses, saying staff will be offered roles elsewhere. The reset emphasizes tighter Whole Foods integration (acquired for $13.7bn in 2017; US corporate pay and benefits extended this summer). Amazon aims to double UK Prime members with access to at least three grocery options via Morrisons, Iceland, Co-op and Gopuff, and will sell fresh groceries on Amazon.co.uk in 2026. The GCA is investigating late supplier payments; Groceries Code compliance is under scrutiny.

articles.title: ‘It’s prime time for rapture talk’: TikTok gets its first ‘world is ending’ moment
articles.trailText: Evangelical Christians on #RaptureTok are warning others of doom on 23 or 24 September – and sharing how they’re prepping
articles.summary: TikTok’s first big apocalypse cycle: #RaptureTok warns the rapture on Sept 23–24. Evangelical creators show prep—selling cars, taking “eternity leave,” removing phone passwords, stashing Dollar Tree Bibles, even debating pets in heaven. The date hype traces to South African preacher Joshua Mhlakela; #rapture has 320k+ posts. Scholars note end-times rumors swell amid turmoil, says Virginia Tech’s Matthew Gabriele; Sojo.net’s Tyler Huckabee dubs it TikTok’s inaugural doomsday moment. Some tie Charlie Kirk’s assassination to resurrection talk. Exvangelicals Jess Lauren and April Ajoy recall Left Behind-fueled rapture anxiety; September spikes link to Rosh Hashanah. Content mixes self-help prep with parody (Shrek VHS “currency”). Expect date-slips, not mea culpas.

articles.title: Pixel 10 Pro XL review: Google’s superphone gets AI and magnetic upgrades
articles.trailText: Top camera, great software, solid battery life and huge screen bolstered by helpful Gemini and Qi2 support
articles.summary: Google’s 6.8in Pixel 10 Pro XL (£1,199/$1,199) is a 232g Android 16 flagship with Tensor G5, 16GB RAM, and 256GB–1TB storage. Highlights: QHD+ 120Hz OLED; strong cameras (50MP main, 48MP ultrawide, 48MP 5x) plus Camera Coach, Add Me, auto Best Take, and Pro Res Zoom >30x with C2PA labels. New Qi2.2 enables 25W wireless and magnetic accessories; battery lasts ~52 hours. Gemini throughout; Magic Cue surfaces timely info; 12 months Google AI Pro + 2TB included; 7 years updates to 2032. 5G/eSIM, Wi‑Fi 7, UWB, BT6; IP68. Gaming trails S25 Ultra; very large/heavy; US lacks SIM tray. 29% recycled, repairable.

articles.title: AI ‘carries risks’ but will help tackle global heating, says UN’s climate chief
articles.trailText: Simon Stiell insists it is vital governments regulate the technology to blunt its dangerous edges
articles.summary: Harnessing AI can speed climate action but needs regulation, UNFCCC chief Simon Stiell said, urging AI platforms run on renewables and be efficient amid surging datacenter energy use. Uses include microgrids, risk mapping and resilient planning. Stiell said the world is aligning with Paris: $2tn clean-energy spend last year led by China, with others scaling. Yet finance lags: of 700+ low-carbon projects, about 15 a year reach production, a $1.6tn opportunity. NDC deadlines extended to this month ahead of COP30; EU, China, India, Russia and Saudi plans are pending. Despite the US Paris exit under Trump, states and firms continue.

articles.title: Nvidia to invest $100bn in OpenAI, bringing the two AI firms together
articles.trailText: Deal will involve two transactions – OpenAI will pay Nvidia for chips, and the chipmaker will invest in the AI startup
articles.summary: Nvidia will invest up to $100bn in OpenAI and supply data-center GPUs under a letter of intent, pairing cash chip purchases by OpenAI with a non‑controlling equity stake for Nvidia. Deliveries start as soon as late 2026, with a first deployment targeted for H2 2026, and at least 10GW of Nvidia compute reserved for OpenAI’s AI infrastructure. The first $10bn investment tranche triggers upon a definitive chip purchase agreement. OpenAI’s latest valuation: ~$500bn; Nvidia previously invested $6.6bn. OpenAI has pledged 49% of profits to Microsoft after a $13bn 2023 deal and is converting to a for‑profit. Nvidia just committed $5bn to Intel; market cap ~$4tn.

articles.title: UK startup Wayve begins testing self-driving tech in Nissan cars on Tokyo’s streets
articles.trailText: London-based AI pioneer in talks to receive $500m investment from Nvidia as it funds its expansion in the US, Germany and Japan
articles.summary: UK startup Wayve is testing its self-driving system on Nissan Ariya EVs on Tokyo streets, aiming for a 2027 consumer launch. Nvidia signed a letter of intent to invest $500m in its next round; Wayve has raised $1.3bn (incl. SoftBank) for US/Germany/Japan expansion while keeping HQ in London. Its end‑to‑end foundation model learns from video/drive data, not hand-coded rules. Initial Nissan rollout is Level‑2 “eyes on, hands off”; cameras+radar are backed by lidar for redundancy. Robotaxi pilots with Uber start in London this spring with safety drivers. Founder Alex Kendall says Nvidia chips power in‑car compute and training; rivals include Tesla, Waymo, Baidu.

articles.title: More Britons view AI as economic risk than opportunity, Tony Blair thinktank finds
articles.trailText: TBI says poll data threatens Keir Starmer’s ambition for UK to become artificial intelligence ‘superpower’
articles.summary: Tony Blair Institute poll (n>3,700) finds 38% of Britons see AI as an economic risk vs 20% as an opportunity; lack of trust is the main barrier. TBI warns this imperils Keir Starmer’s “AI superpower” aim, arguing the UK can lead in adoption, not development (US/China). It projects 1m–3m private‑sector jobs displaced, with offsetting new roles; little evidence yet in graduate hiring. Non‑users are far more worried (>50%) than regular users (~25%). TBI urges five steps: expand public use, showcase benefits (eg NHS wait‑time cuts), measure impacts, regulate responsibly, build skills. Government touts skills drives; expects 10m workers using AI by 2035.

articles.title: Donald Trump and Elon Musk meet and shake hands months after messy split
articles.trailText: Musk, who bankrolled Trump’s presidential campaign and later became an advisor to him, greeted the president at the memorial for Charlie Kirk
articles.summary: At a Glendale, Arizona stadium memorial for slain activist Charlie Kirk (killed Sept 10 at a Utah campus), President Donald Trump and Elon Musk shook hands and chatted, prompting reconciliation speculation months after a bitter split. Musk, who owns X, donated $270m to Trump's campaign and briefly led the White House's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), which cut thousands of federal jobs. They fell out over Trump's flagship tax-and-spending bill, trading barbs online; Musk cited 'Epstein files,' Trump mused about deporting him. The White House posted video on X; Musk posted, 'For Charlie.' It is unclear if this was their first meeting since the rift.

articles.title: Chatbot site depicting child sexual abuse images raises fears over misuse of AI
articles.trailText: Child safety watchdog calls for child protection guidelines to be built into AI models from the outset
articles.summary: The UK Internet Watch Foundation (IWF) found a chatbot website hosting AI-generated, photorealistic child sexual abuse material (CSAM) and explicit role-play with preteen characters. Icons expanded into full-screen abuse images that persisted as chat backgrounds; IWF flagged 17 images illegal under the Protection of Children Act. The site, accessible in the UK, appears China-owned, is hosted on US servers, and logged ~60,000 visits in July. IWF reports a 400% YoY surge in AI-generated CSAM in H1, including more video. IWF and NSPCC urge mandatory child-safety-by-design rules for AI. The UK plans an AI bill and crime and policing bill offences; Ofcom cites Online Safety Act enforcement. NCMEC was notified.

articles.title: Meta exposé author faces bankruptcy after ban on criticising company
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Sarah Wynn-Williams faces $50,000 fine every time she breaches order banning her from criticising Meta
articles.summary: Former Meta executive Sarah Wynn-Williams faces financial peril after Meta enforced a non-disparagement clause from her 2017 exit, with $50,000 damages per breach; UK MP Louise Haigh told parliament she is 'on the verge of bankruptcy.' A court order bars Wynn-Williams from promoting her memoir, Careless People. She alleges Meta worked with Beijing on censorship and mishandled teens and harassment; Meta denies this, says she was fired for poor performance/toxic behavior, and notes she has paid nothing to date. The book has sold 150,000+ copies; she testified to a US Senate panel in April. Lawmakers urge Meta to halt UK arbitration.

articles.title: British AI startup beats humans in international forecasting competition
articles.trailText: ManticAI ranked eighth in the Metaculus Cup, leaving some believing bots’ prediction skills could soon overtake experts
articles.summary: British startup ManticAI, co-founded by ex-DeepMind researcher Toby Shevlane, placed 8th in Metaculus’s summer Cup, outperforming many pros across 60 questions (e.g., Samoa’s election winner, US acres burned) scored on 1 Sept. CEO Deger Turan said AI could match/top elite humans by 2029 but still trails on complex, interdependent forecasts and logic checks. Mantic assigns tasks to multiple LLM agents (OpenAI, Google, DeepSeek) to research, simulate and update daily, countering groupthink. Studies (Tetlock) still favor humans; Good Judgment’s Warren Hatch urges human+AI; forecasters noted rapid bot gains. Ben Shindel noted being briefly outdone; a year ago the best bot ranked ~300.

articles.title: Parents outraged as Meta uses photos of schoolgirls in ads targeting man
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Instagram pictures of girls as young as 13 were posted to promote Threads site ‘as bait’, campaigner says
articles.summary: Meta promoted Threads on Instagram by inserting “suggested threads” featuring back-to-school photos of girls aged 13–15—faces and often names visible—into a 37-year-old man’s feed, angering parents. One mother’s “private” Instagram auto–cross-posted publicly to Threads; another had a public IG. A post from an account with 267 followers drew nearly 7,000 views, 90% from non-followers, half over 44, 90% men. The man said only schoolgirls were shown, no boys, implying sexualisation. Meta says using publicly shared adult-account posts complies with policies and can be disabled; it doesn’t recommend teens’ posts. Campaigner Beeban Kidron called it sexualised “bait” and urged Ofcom action under new online safety codes.

articles.title: Trump says Xi Jinping has agreed to approve TikTok deal, but details unclear
articles.trailText: Trump’s statement suggests preliminary agreement between leaders in the first direct contact between them since June
articles.summary: Donald Trump said Xi Jinping approved a preliminary TikTok deal after their first call since June, but terms and a signing date remain unclear. The framework would shift U.S. operations to American control: an Oracle-led investor stake, a seven-seat U.S. board with six Americans, and U.S. control of the algorithm, per the White House. WSJ says investors would pay a fee to the U.S. Talks advanced in Madrid (Treasury’s Scott Bessent; China’s He Lifeng) amid a temporary trade-war pause and a 10 Nov deadline. Beijing urged a fair, non-discriminatory environment. Trump touted progress on trade, fentanyl and Ukraine, floated Xi meetings; China hasn’t confirmed.

articles.title: UK Snapchat predator jailed for 14 years for raping girl, 12, and exploiting dozens of others
articles.trailText: Stuart Latham admitted 49 offences in one of UK’s biggest online child sexual abuse cases
articles.summary: Stuart Latham, 22, was jailed for a minimum 14 years after raping a 12-year-old and exploiting dozens in one of Greater Manchester police’s biggest online child abuse cases. He admitted 49 offences against at least 41 victims, with 4,000 indecent images seized (1,000+ category A). Posing as “Josh” on Snapchat and other platforms, he mass-messaged girls aged 11-13, solicited images for money, then threatened leaks. Arrested Dec 2023, he continued offending while on bail. Preston crown court heard at least three US victims. GMP called him highly dangerous and urged stricter age checks and more victims to come forward.

articles.title: Gordon Thompson obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives : Electrical engineer who worked on the development of printed circuit boards
articles.summary: Electrical engineer Gordon Thompson, 94, helped pioneer printed circuit boards at ICL Manchester. Early career at Orford Ness (A&AEE site); national service with the Royal Corps of Signals in Sudan. Worked at RAF Farnborough, English Electric (Luton), Associated Transistors, then Ferranti→ICL; declined a 1974 US Amp Inc move to Winston‑Salem. Earned an ONC at Letchworth via night school. Aided the 1953 North Sea flood clear‑up. Born Orford; mother died early; raised by stepmother; father served Navy/RAF. Keen cricketer and badminton player. Retired after Fujitsu’s 2002 ICL takeover. Met wife Naida in 1957 (d.2019); survived by two sons and four grandchildren.

articles.title: Meta announces first Ray-Ban smart glasses with in-built augmented reality display
articles.trailText: Meta Ray-Ban Display have screen on inside of lens that can translate conversations, display information on landmarks and give directions
articles.summary: Meta unveiled three AI wearables, headlined by Meta Ray-Ban Display — Wayfarer-style glasses with a color HUD projected on the right lens for text, images, captions/translations, turn-by-turn, viewfinder, and video calls. Touch/voice control plus a water-resistant Neural Band bracelet uses EMG to detect pinches, swipes, rotations; handwriting coming. Works via Bluetooth with iOS/Android and Meta apps; up to 6h use, 30h with case. US 30 Sep, $799; UK/FR/IT/CA early 2026. Also: Oakley Meta Vanguard sport glasses (no display), 66g, 9h, Garmin integration, auto milestone clips, Strava sharing; £499/€549/$499, ships 21 Oct. Revamped Ray-Ban Meta AI: double battery, higher-res video, £379/€419/$379/A$599.
